abstract: Van Zeck, commissioner of the public debt, quietly runs one of the government’s truly indispensable operations. He is not a policy maker. He does not decide how much to borrow. He just makes sure the money is borrowed at the lowest possible cost to the U.S. government.
snippet: Van Zeck, commissioner of the public debt, quietly runs one of the government’s truly indispensable operations. He is not a policy maker. He does not decide how much to borrow. He just makes sure the money is borrowed at the lowest possible cost t...
lead_paragraph: In a city full of pompous politicians and bombastic bureaucrats, Van Zeck, the commissioner of the public debt, quietly runs one of the government’s truly indispensable operations. He is not a policy maker. He does not decide how much to borrow. He just makes sure the money is borrowed, in a regular and predictable way, at the lowest possible cost to the government over time, The New York Times’s Robert Pear wrote.

headline.main: The Man Who Sells America’s I.O.U.s

abstract: Gerald Marzorati is answering questions from readers Aug. 24-28, 2009.
snippet: Gerald Marzorati is answering questions from readers Aug. 24-28, 2009.
lead_paragraph: Gerald Marzorati, assistant managing editor at The Times and editor of The Times Magazine is answering questions from readers on the weekly magazine, the T Style magazines and other topics Aug. 24-28, 2009. He previously answered questions in July 2006. Questions may be e-mailed to askthetimes@nytimes.com.

headline.main: Talk to the Times: Assistant Managing Editor Gerald Marzorati
